NAME.WIZARD: > /> Please select Group Number assigned to the torch. /> /> If you wish to set up a new Torch, then select New Torch. If you wish to view or change an existing torch, then press Select Torch Number assigned to the Torch. /> /> /> /> Input a comment to further identify the torch. The comment can be up to 29 characters. /> /> X, Y, Z describes the three-dimensional location of the tool center point relative to the center of the faceplate. Input the measurement between the center line of the faceplate and the tool center point in the X direction. Input the measurement between the center line of the robot arm and the Tool Center Point in the Y direction. Input the measurement from the center of the faceplate of the robot to the point on the tool that performs work. The Rotation of a position has three components, (W, P, R), which describe the three-dimensional rotation of the position. Input the measurement of W which is the rotation of the Torch about X. Input the measurement of P which is the rotation of the Torch about Y. Input the measurement of R which is the rotation of the Torch about Z. /> /> /> /> /> /> If you wish to set up new weights for the Torch, then select New Weights. If you wish to select existing weights, then please select Weights assigned to the Torch. /> /> /> Specify the weight of your torch. Input the weight of the torch. Input a comment to further identify the payload. Setup Torch Center of Mass. Enter offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Input the center of mass in the X direction. This is the balance point of the torch in the X direction. The unit is cm. Input the center of mass in the Y direction. This is the balance point of the torch in the Y direction. The unit is cm. Input the center of mass in the Z direction. This is the balance point of the torch in the Z direction. The unit is cm. Congratulations! Your Torch Setup is complete. Press NEXT STEP to continue. Please refer MORE INFO below to jog the robot in the Torch frame you just taught. /> /> /> /> /> /> />
NAME.MENU: Welcome to the Torch Setup Guide. In this Guide, you will set up items such as the Torch Center Position, and Torch Center of Mass for the torch attached to the robot.

Torch Setup Additional Information

In this setup you will be specifying details about your torch, such as torch dimensions, angles, and other applicable parameters so that the robot can properly make use of the torch. You can return to this setup to change any setting at any time. If you do not want to save your changes, press CANCEL.

Choose whether you want to enter your torch data directly, or use the robot to record the torch information.
Do you know the dimensions of your torch and want to enter them directly?
Would you like to use the robot determine the torch dimensions?

Choose a method to record the Torch Frame.
Use the six point method to define the location and orientation of the Torch frame when the values cannot be measured and directly entered. Use XZ when it is easier for you to record a point in the +Z direction.

Teach Method Additional Information

Six Point(XZ):
The six point method requires three points that define the direction vector for the tool, and three points that define the location of the tool center point.
Select Record the First Point to record the current position as the first point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach the First Point Additional Information

Record the First Point:
Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Try to align to tool so that it is parallel to the Z of the WORLD coordinate system. When you have finished, select Record the First Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record the Second Point to record the current position as the second point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach the Second Point Additional Information

Record the Second Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about the Z axis in WORLD 180 degrees but not more than 360 degrees, if possible. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches the reference point. Select Record the Second Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record the Third Point to record the current position as the third point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach the Third Point Additional Information

Record the Third Point:
Jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Rotate the tool about either the X or Y axis of the WORLD coordinate. Jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record the Third Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record Orient Origin Point to record the current position as the orient origin point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach Orient Origin Point Additional Information

Record Orient Origin Point:
To record the orientation of the origin, jog away from the reference point so as not to accidentally hit it. Jog the robot so that the desired tool +Z axis is parallel to the Z axis of the world frame, pointing in the -Z direction. Make sure that the X axis of the tool is parallel to the X axis of the world frame. Using only the X, Y, and Z keys, jog the robot so that the tool tip touches a reference point. Select Record Orient Origin Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record X Direction Point to record the current position as the X direction point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach X Direction Point Additional Information

Record X Direction Point:
To record the X direction point, jog the robot so that the tool moves in the +X direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the X axis of the tool is aligned with the world X axis, jog in the +X direction. Select Record X Direction Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.
Select Record Z Direction Point to record the current position as the Z direction point. Select Jog Assist Menu to jog the robot or move to the recorded position. /> />

Teach Z Direction Point Additional Information

Record Z Direction Point:
To record the Z direction point, jog the robot so that the tool moves in the +Z direction at least 250 mm or more. For example, if the Z axis of the tool is aligned with the world Z axis, jog in the +Z direction. Select Record Z Direction Point.

Jog Assist Menu:
To move to a recorded position, select Jog Assist Menu, press and hold the SHIFT key and press MOVE TO.

Torch Number Additional Information

Active Torch checkbox is allowed you to set the Torch Number as the active Torch frame. You can select only one Torch frame at a time to be active. You can jog the robot in the active Torch frame.

Offsets (XYZ) Additional Information

X is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the faceplate. The X direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame. Y is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the arm. The Y direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame. Z is defined by the reference X, Y, Z frame on the end of the arm. The Z direction extends in the direction indicated by the reference X, Y, Z frame.

Rotations (WPR) Additional Information

The orientation of a position is expressed as three dimensions, (W, P, R) which are measured in degrees of rotation about the X, Y, and Z axes. For example, 0,-90, 0 means that the position is rotated -90 degrees about the Y axis and is not rotated about the X or Z axes.

Weight Additional Information

Check and input the weight value of the torch to use. Tapping Advanced button shows you Center of Mass input screen.

Torch Center of Mass Additional Information

Torch X Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the up and down offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are up. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

Torch Y Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the side offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are to the right of the faceplate when viewed from behind the faceplate. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

Torch Z Center of Mass (cm):
This item is the offset of the payload center of gravity from the center of the faceplate. Positive (+) values are out from the faceplate. There are 0.39 inches per centimeter.

Torch Comment Additional Information

Torch Comment is extra information of the Torch. It is composed with the "Tool Frame Number" and a comment.
The "Tool Frame Number" is a ID of particular frame (coordinate system) assigned for the Torc h. This is set automatically, and you can't change the value in this wizard.
Comment is a note for the Torch. If there is nothing to state, you can skip it. In 29 characters you can input such as a short memo, or a label for the Torch.

TCP Verification Additional Information

Rotate the tool about the X axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

Rotate the tool about the Y axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

Rotate the tool about the Z axis of the TOOL coordinates. If the Tool Center Point (TCP) is correct, it will remain stationary during rotational moves.

NAME.MENU:
Choose a template to create your program.
Select Blank Template to start with an empty program to which you can add instructions.
Comment1"
Comment2"
Comment3"
Comment4"
Comment5"
Comment6"
Comment7"
Comment8"
Comment9"
Comment10"

Program Name

When you create a new program, you must give it a unique program name. The name should be descriptive and it should tell you what the program does. The name can be from one to 36 characters long, must start with a letter, and it must contain no spaces or special characters other than an underscore.

Program Comment

The comment can be up to 16 characters.

Template Programs

Template programs are sample programs that can be used to create your teach pendant program. They contain default instructions that perform typical robot operations. After you choose a template, it will be copied to a new program to which you can modify or add other instructions.

Check which motion groups the program will control. If the program will not contain any motion, then select No Motion.
/>

Group Information

When you create a program, you define which group of axes, or motion group, that the program will control. Motion groups define different groups of axes that can be used for independent pieces of equipment, positioning tables, opening devices, and other axes. Only those groups configured on your robot will be shown. Select which motion group(s) will be controlled by this program. If you do not select a group, you cannot add motion instructions to your program.

Choose the type of program you want to create.
Typical Robot Program creates a program as a .TP (Teach Pendant) program, which can include almost any instruction available in the robot including motion instructions. This is typical for most operations.
Advanced Program creates a .TP program which can be created for specific motion groups or with no motion. Additional types, such as Job (.JB), Process (.PR), Collection (.CO), Macro (.MC), or Condition (.CH) may be available based on controller settings.

Choose the type of program you want to create.
/>
/>
/>
/>
/>
/>

Program Type Information

Note: Your controller may not have all program types available.

TP Program

TP Program creates a .TP program which can be created for specific motion groups or with no motion.

Job

Job creates a .JB program which can be used as the main program. When you run production, you run the job that corresponds to the task you want to perform. The job contains program calls to each of the processes that will be performed during production.

Process

Process creates a .PR program. A process is a program that directs the robot to perform a specific task.

Collection

Collection creates a .CO program which is used to collect programs together to simplify program maintenance.

Macro

Macro creates a .MC program which can include any instructions and function as a typical .TP program. However, macro programs can be set up to be executed in these unique ways:
  • Pressing a Teach Pendant User Key
  • Selecting an item on the MANUAL FCNTS Macros screen
  • Issuing an input signal: DI, RI, UI, and Marker

Condition

Condition creates a .CH program which will monitor events on the controller and perform actions when the events become true. Only the WHEN instruction is available in a condition program.
We perform the tasks for program teaching of a Pick-and-Place program using the following steps. Perform Create a program first.
Create a program is finished. Proceed to Edit the program.
The Pick-and-Place program you created moves the robot as shown below. Next, jog the robot (manually) to set up the four motion points contained in the program.
Jog the robot to the starting point. You will actually move the robot in the following steps.
Turn the Operator Panel Mode Switch to T1.
Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON. The red button on the upper right corner is the Emergency Stop button. In case of emergency, press this button to immediately stop the robot.
To select the method to move the robot, press the COORD key several times until WORLD appears on the screen.

The DEADMAN switch is a three-position switch used to ensure safe robot operation. Hold one of the DEADMAN switches on the back of the TP to the second (middle) position while you perform the following operation steps.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the RESET key to reset the alarm shown in the status window.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot above the pick point.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -Z(J3) key to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the point to pick up the workpiece.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the pass point for moving to the place point.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
Jog the robot to the point to place the workpiece.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot. Use +Z(J3) to jog above the place point.
Jog the robot away from the place point.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and select Record the Position to record the position in the program.

/> />
Edit the program is finished. Proceed to Execute the program.
The robot motions you have set up so far are contained in the program shown below. Next, execute the Pick-and-Place program from the first line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.
If the Step LED is lit, hold the DEADMAN switch and press the STEP key to turn off the Step LED. The continuous execution mode will be selected.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the FWD key to execute the program from beginning to end at once. Keep holding the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key during the program execution.
You have completed the Pick-and-Place program. Select FINISH to enter the TP Editor where you can modify the program and touchup the points.

MENELE.text: Turn the TP Enable switch to ON to edit the program.

> /> /> To restore your files press NEXT STEP.

NAME.MENU: Select backup device. If no device appears, insert valid USB stick or Memory Card, then select "Refresh Device List". /> /> /> /> /> /> />

Backup Device Additional Information

Front Panel USB (UD1)

This port is on the front panel of most controllers.

Memory Card (MC)

You need to open the cabinet to access this device slot.

Teach Pendant USB (UT1)

This port is located on the side of the TP.

Select the type of backup you wish to perform.
/>
/>
/>
/>

Backup Type Additional Information

System Backup

This will backup all the files necessary to restore the system to the current state.

Image Backup

Perform an Image backup.

Full System Backup

This will backup all the files necessary to restore the system to the current state with readable (ASCII) files.

This is equivelent to performing a MD:\*.* copy.

Full System and Image Backup

This will perform a System Backup with Text Files (MD:\*.* copy) in a date/time stamped "MD" folder, followed by an Image Backup in a date/time stamped "IMG" folder.

NAME.MENU:
/> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> Select your geographic region. Americas Europe Asia Pacific Select the level of Network Accessibility that you want. All network access is disabled. The system will get its setup from the network router.

Security Information

The robot controller is designed to be open and accessible. Robots should be protected by a Firewall to avoid any unauthorized access. The robot is not intended to be connected directly to a public network. Use care in providing any external access to the robot controller.

The accessibility settings here allow you to provide a certain level of accessibility to prevent inadvertent access to Web Services, KCL Access and FTP Write. These settings should be made based on your particular environment. Network is not set up. You must select Set Up Network in order to proceed to the next step. /> Your network has been set up. Select Change Network Settings to modify network setup. />

Network Setup Additional Information

Setting up the network allows you to access the robot from an external device like a PC or tablet. After you set it up, your robot will connect to the network. You must set up your network to continue. If you do not have a network set up at your facility, press PREV STEP and select No Network Access to skip this step. > /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> > /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> > /> /> /> /> /> /> /> /> Press NEXT STEP or press FINISH to proceed. For novice users, this continues step-by-step robot setup assistance. Even for expert users, this is an easy way to complete required settings. If you are an expert user and already know how to set up your robot, this exits step-by-step assistance.

Welcome to

Guided Setup

A step-by-step guide to setting up your robot using FANUC's intuitive setup Guides.

Press NEXT STEP to begin or MORE INFO for more information.

Select the alarm at the top of the screen for more information on the active alarm. />

Please review all applicable safety documentation for your system before you continue.

For more information, press MORE INFO below.

Press NEXT STEP and proceed when you understand the safety considerations.

Safety Information

The owner or user should consult the standards for robots, e.g. ISO 10218 and ANSI/RIA R15.06, to ensure compliance with requests for Robotics System design, usability, operation, maintenance, and service.

Additionally, as the owner, employer, or user of a robotic system, it is your responsibility to arrange for the training of the operator of a robot system to recognize and respond to known hazards associated with your robotic system, and to be aware of and follow the recommended operating procedures for your particular application and robot installation.

iHMI Guides Additional Information

  • You can return to iHMI Guides at any time and change any of your answers.
  • Choosing an item on the screen will display the NEXT STEP key.
  • Press NEXT STEP to continue.
  • Press PREV STEP to return to an earlier answer and change it.
  • You can also select a different step in the iHMI Guides by selecting it in the step pane on the left of the screen.
  • Press CANCEL to quit and the Guide will start over from the beginning.
  • Press FINISH when you have completed a setup, and iHMI Guides will record your settings.
Press EXIT to return to iHMI Guides. /> /> /> /> Select editor type. The Touch Panel Editor (Icon Editor) is touch based and easy to use for novice users. This editor requires the touch panel iPendant. Please select the Regular Editor if your iPendant does not have a touch panel. The Regular Rditor is commonly used by experienced users. If your iPendant doesn't have touch panel, please select this editor. If you have never operated a FANUC robot select one of the following for assistance. These are available from the HOME page at any time. /> /> /> />

NAME.WIZARD: > /> /> /> /> This is the name of the controller on the network. Using the digits and . in the keypad, please enter the IP address in the form 192.168.1.100 The subnet mask is typically 255.255.255.0 but might be 255.255.240.0 depending on the subnet size. Ask your system administrator. Please enter with the . using the keypad. This is the router IP Address. Usually it is the same as your IP Address, except that the final digit is a 1. This is required if you are accessing a network outside of your local sub-net. This is the MAC Address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user. This is the MAC address of the robot controller. It is not settable by the user This is the name of the controller on the network. MENU.text: DHCP was not successful consult with your network administrator if the problem persists.

NAME.MENU:
/> /> /> /> /> /> /> Selecting Manual settings will disble DHCP. Continue? EtherNet/IP CIP Safety is enabled on the Robot.
A power-cycle is required to change the robot IP address on this interface. In this Guide, you will set up the Network for one of the Ethernet ports. Press NEXT STEP to start. Select a method to set up the network. The system will receive the network setup from the router. Input the network setup parameters manually.

Network Information

By selecting automatic, the system will search for an IP address from a router or other network service. This IP address is not guaranteed to be the same every time, so consider setting up a static IP address so that the server functions of the robot are always available on the same IP address. This setting is also required for network I/O like EIP or Profinet.

You can still set up and run the robot without setting up the network, but you will not be able to connect to the robot with your Apple, Android or PC device. Select the level of Network Accessibility that you want. Load your own configuration file. Most protocols are disabled. Web server, FTP, and SNPX are accessible. All network capabilities are enabled including external iPendant access. Choose the selected port for your Ethernet connection. Make sure that an active Ethernet cable is plugged into the selected port before proceeding. Port 3 functionality is limited. Press MORE INFO If the Enhanced Vision Ethernet Port option (R825) is installed, then the Vision Ethernet Port (CD38C) Port 3 can also be configured. This port is only available when the option is installed.

Ethernet port #3 supports:

  • Vision Ethernet camera
  • FTP File Transfer Protocol
  • HTTP Web Server
Other protocols including DHCP for automatic configuration are NOT supported.

Connect Information

You should be able to connect to the link information(URL) on this page from your smartphone, tablet or PC.

You can connect to the robot on the local network only. You cannot connect from an outside network or LTE connection. If you are connecting through Wi-Fi, the robot must be on the same network as your Wi-Fi access point.

If you see this icon, there is an error connecting the robot to the network. Try the step again.

If you still cannot connect please check the following:

  • Did you pay attention to notifications on prior steps?
  • Can you connect to other devices on the network with your device?
  • Are you accessing your local Network?
  • Are you using the IP address in the Robot Link as recommended?
  • Did you manually enter a unique IP address?
  • Did you try powering the robot off and on?
If you wish to connect using the robot name contact you network administrator.

This tutorial guides you to jog (manually move) the robot using the teach pendant (TP).

You will experience the followings:
- Joint jog
- Cartesian jog (X, Y, Z)
- Tool jog (X, Y, Z)

You can show description by tapping the MORE INFO button on each page.

Introduction

This tutorial describes how to jog the robot.
Jogging is manually moving the robot axes by pressing keys on the TP. Manually moving the robot is necessary to position it for programming.
The manner in which the robot moves when the keys are pressed, will vary depending on which coordinate system you have chosen. You can choose JOINT, one of the Cartesian coordinate systems, or Tool.
Joint
When TP keys are pressed cooresponding to a particular axis, only that axis will move.
Cartesian (X,Y,Z)
When TP keys are pressed, the current programmed robot tool will move in line with the chosen vector, (X, Y, or Z) corresponding to the chosen Cartesian coordinate system.
Tool
When TP keys are pressed, the current programmed robot tool will move in line with the chosen vector, (X, Y, or Z) corresponding to the Tool coordinate system. This Tool coordinate system is typically taught using the physical tool as a guide so that the Z vector of the system aligns with the torch nozzle.

The following items affect the way the robot jogs as well as the axes that will move while jogging:
Jog speed - How fast the robot moves when jogging
Coordinate system - The way the robot moves when jogging
Turn the Operator Panel Mode Switch to T1.

Select Mode on Operator Panel

The Mode Switch is used to select the most appropriate way to operate the robot, depending on the conditions and situation. The operation modes are AUTO, T1, and T2, although T2 is not available on some robots.
T1 and T2 are test or teach modes, and are used in conjunction with TP use, whereas AUTO is used when the TP is not being used to control the robot.
T1 restricts the robot to a safe speed (typically less than 250 mm/sec).

Turn the Teach Pendant (TP) Enable switch to ON.
The red button on the upper right corner is the Emergency Stop button.
In case of emergency, press this button to immediately stop the robot.

Enable Teach Pendant

Although the TP enable switch is labeled OFF and ON, it does not remove power from (turn off) or supply power to (turn on) the TP. It does, however, enable the TP to allow certain functions such as jogging the robot.
To select the method to move the robot, press the COORD key several times until JOINT appears on the screen.

Robot Movement (Joint Jog)

The COORD key allows the selection of the coordinate system that is to be used for jogging.
Joint coordinate system allows you to jog each joint or axis of the robot individually. Therefore, to jog the robot one axis at a time, press the COORD key until JOINT appears.

The DEADMAN switch is a three-position switch used to ensure safe robot operation.
Hold one of the DEADMAN switches on the back of the TP to the second (middle) position while you perform the following operation steps.

DEADMAN Switch

The DEADMAN switch is an enabling device with three positions. When it is completely released and the TP enable switch is ON, the robot will be in an emergency stop (e-stop) condition.
When it is completely pulled in and the TP enable switch is ON, the robot will also be in an e-stop condition. Only when the device is pulled in to the center position and the TP enable switch is ON, will motion be allowed.

Note:
When the TP enable switch is OFF, the DEADMAN switch is ignored.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.

Motion Speed (Joint Jog)

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move.
When jogging the robot, this speed is a percentage of the maximum jog speed of the robot.
When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed.
The maximum value that can be chosen is 100%. The minimum value that can be chosen is VFINE (very fine) which moves the robot a very small amount each time a jog key is pressed.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the RESET key to reset the alarm shown in the status window.
* If you release your hand from the DEADMAN switch, an alarm occurs again.

Reset Alarm

Whenever the robot is faulted, it will not move. Before jogging the robot, any faults must be cleared. If all of the conditions that might lead to a fault have been addressed, simply pressing the RESET key will clear the residual fault condition.
If a fault condition still exists, the robot will remain faulted even after the RESET key has been pressed. If this occurs, further investigation is required. Perhaps the problem is something simple, such as an e-stop button having been pressed.

After resetting alarm, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -X(J1) or +X(J1) key.
The corresponding joint of the robot moves.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Joint Jog (J1)

Joint will allow you to jog individual robot axes in the positve or negative directions.

The jog keys have a dual designation. For example a jog key might have an +X and a (J1) on it. When you are in JOINT, the X can be ignored. You are simply jogging J1 in the positive or negative direction when you press the +X(J1) or -X(J1) key.

For joints J2 to J6, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -YJ2) to +Z(J6) keys to jog the robot.
The corresponding joint of the robot moves.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Joint Jog (J2 - J6)

Joint will allow you to jog individual robot axes in the positve or negative directions.

The jog keys have a dual designation. For example a jog key might have a +Y and a (J2) on it. When you are in JOINT, the Y can be ignored. You are simply jogging J2 in the positive or negative direction when you press the +Y(J2) or -Y(J2) key.
To select the method to move the robot, press the COORD key several times until WORLD appears on the screen.

Robot Movement (Cartesian Jog)

When TP keys are pressed while in an XYZ or Cartesian coordinate system, the current programmed robot tool will move in line with the chosen vector (X, Y, or Z) corresponding to the chosen Cartesian coordinate system.

The WORLD coordinate system (frame) is the default frame of the robot. All XYZ robot positions are ultimately taught in reference to this frame.
It is a coordinate system wherein the X vector extends from the robot outwards towards its front, the Y vector points to the left from the robot's perspective, and the Z vector points up from the base.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.

Motion Speed (Cartesian Jog)

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move. When jogging the robot, this speed is a percentage of the maximum jog speed of the robot.
When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed.
The maximum value that can be chosen is 100%. The minimum value that can be chosen is VFINE (very fine) which moves the robot a very small amount each time a jog key is pressed.

After resetting alarm, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -Z(J3) or +Z(J3) key.
The robot moves to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Cartesian Jog (Z Direction)

Pressing the jog key corresponding to the Z axis of WORLD frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to move up or down depending on whether the +Z(J3) or -Z(J3) key was pressed (assuming the robot is mounted on the floor).

For the X or Y direction, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the keys for each direction.
The robot moves to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Cartesian Jog (X/Y Directions)

Pressing the jog key corresponding to the X axis of WORLD frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to move out in front of the robot (away from the robot) or in (toward the robot) depending on whether the +X(J1) or -X(J1) key is pressed.

Pressing the jog key corresponding to the Y axis of WORLD frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to move left or right from the robot's perspective depending on whether the +Y(J2) or -Y(J2) key was pressed.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -Z(J6) or +Z(J6) key.
The wrist of robot rotates to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Cartesian Jog (Rotation around Z)

Pressing the rotational jog key corresponding to the Z of WORLD frame (key with an arched arrow above the Z) will cause the current programmed robot tool to rotate around the Z axis of the WORLD frame.

For rotation around X or Y, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the keys for each direction.
The wrist of robot rotates to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Cartesian Jog (Rotation around X/Y)

Pressing the rotational jog key corresponding to the X or Y axis of WORLD frame (key with an arched arrow above the X or Y) will cause the current programmed robot tool to rotate around the X or Y axis of the WORLD frame.
To select the method to move the robot, press the COORD key several times until TOOL appears on the screen.

Robot Movement (Tool Jog)

Tool is a coordinate system (frame) designed to align X, Y, and Z with the robot's physical tool. For example, in welding the frame is typically programmed such that the Z of the frame aligns with the torch nozzle.

When TP keys are pressed, the current programmed robot tool will move in line with the welding torch. This makes it easier to jog the robot when working in close proximity to the workpiece.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.

Motion Speed (Tool Jog)

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move.
When jogging the robot, this speed is a percentage of the maximum jog speed of the robot.
When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed.
The maximum value that can be chosen is 100%. The minimum value that can be chosen is VFINE (very fine) which moves the robot a very small amount each time a jog key is pressed.

After resetting alarm, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -Z(J3) or +Z(J3) key.
The robot moves to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Tool Jog (Z Direction)

Pressing the jog key correspoinding to the Z axis of TOOL frame will cause the welding torch to move in line with the nozzle (providing the tool frame has been properly taught using the six-point method).
If the +Z(J3) key is pressed, the torch will move in the direction of wire retract, typically away from the work. If the -Z(J3) key is pressed, the torch will move in the direction of wire feed, typically toward the work.

For the X or Y direction, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the keys for each direction.
The robot moves to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Tool Jog (X/Y Directions)

Pressing the jog key correspoinding to the X or Y axis of TOOL frame will cause the welding torch to move in line with the nozzle.

The welding torch moves on front-back direction by pressing the -X(J1) or +X(J1) key.
The welding torch moves on left-right direction by pressing the -Y(J2) or +Y(J2) key.

Note:
 The X,Y and Z directions of TOOL frame can be varied by the rotation of the welding torch.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the -Z(J6) or +Z(J6) key. The wrist of robot rotates to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Tool Jog (Rotation around Z)

Pressing the rotational jog key correspoinding to the Z axis of TOOL frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to rotate around the Z axis of the TOOL frame.

Tool rotation around the Z axis can be accomplished by pressing the -Z(J6) or +Z(J6) key with the arched arrow at the top. Pressing this key will rotate the tool around Z.
This motion is also known as Roll, often designated by the letter R.

For rotation around X or Y, hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the keys for each direction.
The wrist of robot rotates to the direction corresponding to the pressed key.
* The robot will not move in an alarm state.

Tool Jog (Rotation around X/Y)

Pressing the rotational jog key correspoinding to the X or Y axis of TOOL frame will cause the current programmed robot tool to rotate around the corresponding axis of the TOOL frame.

Tool rotation around the X axis can be accomplished by pressing the -X(J4) or +X(J4) key with the arched arrow at the top. Pressing this key will rotate the tool around X.
This motion is also known as Yaw, often designated by the letter W.

Tool rotation around the Y axis can be accomplished by pressing the -Y(J5) or +Y(J5) key with the arched arrow at the top. Pressing this key will rotate the tool around Y.
This motion is also known as Pitch, often designated by the letter P.

All steps in the "Jog a robot" tutorial have been completed.
Tap BACK PREV and proceed to the "Weld preparations" tutorial.

This tutorial guides you through welding preparations.

You will experience the followings:
- Wire inching
- Gas operations
- Enabling or disabling arc welding

 * You are required to complete "Jog a robot" tutorial in advance.

Hold the SHIFT key and press the WIRE+ key to inch the wire.
When you keep pressing the WIRE+ key for more than 2 seconds, the wire will be inched at high-speed.

Wire Inching

It is sometimes necessary to manually feed wire through the torch. This is known as "inching" the wire.
This can easily be done by pressing the SHIFT key and then the WIRE + key.

Note:
Some robot software might not require that the SHIFT key be pressed in conjuction with the WIRE + or WIRE - key.

Hold the SHIFT key and press the WIRE- key to inch back the wire.
When too long wire is drawn out, cut it instead of inching backward.

Adjust the wire stickout length to 15 mm by holding the SHIFT key and pressing the WIRE+ or WIRE- key.
If your wire diameter is less than 1.2 mm, adjust to 12mm.

Adjust Length

The lengths of wire given in this step are a suggestion. You may, based on experience and the application, choose to vary this length slightly.

Make sure that valves of gas regulator and tank are already open.
Hold the SHIFT key and press the GAS STATUS key. The gas flows and automatically stops. You can immediately stop the flow by holding the SHIFT key and press the GAS STATUS key again.
Control the gas flow rate from 15 to 25 ml/mm using the regulator.

When Weld is turned off in the status window, hold the SHIFT key and press the WELD ENBL key to turn on the Weld LED.
Arc welding is enabled.

Switch Weld Enable Mode (Enabling)

This step gives you the opportunity to test the Weld Enable funciton. If Weld Enable is not on, welding will not take place even if a programmed weld instruction is executed.

Hold the SHIFT key and press the WELD ENBL key to turn off the lit Weld LED in the status window.
Arc welding is disabled.

All steps in the "Weld preparations" tutorial have been completed.
Tap BACK PREV and proceed to the "Edit a program" tutorial.

This tutorial guides you to create a program using the teach pendant (TP).

You will experience the followings:
- Creating a program using the program creation guide
- Editing the created program

* You are required to complete "Welding preparations" tutorial in advance.

You are going to create a TP program to move the robot as shown below.
To create and edit the program, you will need to work in other screens. You can return to this tutorial at any time and continue where you left off by tapping HOME -> Tutorial -> Edit a program.

About the Program

This program will make the robot approach the metal plates to be welded, strike an arc at the start point, move along the weld joint, end the arc at the end point, and then return to a position at or near the starting position.

This program has five positions:
P[1] is referred to in this tutorial as the Standby Position and in the program itself as Reference Point.
P[2] is referred to, both in this tutorial and in the program itself, as Approach Point.
P[3] is referred to in this tutorial as Start Point and in the program itself as Weld Start Point.
P[4] is referred to in this tutorial as End Point and in the program itself as Weld End Point.
P[5] is referred to in this tutorial as Retract Point and in the program itself as Escape Point.
Make sure that the jigs and workpieces you are going to use are correctly placed.

Checking Workpieces

Although every situation will be different, in its most basic form this means situating and properly grounding two pieces of metal such that they form a lap joint that can be welded.

Start the program creation guide.
Tap HOME -> CREATE PROG..

You are going to create a simple tutorial welding program.
Tap Arc Welding Template in the template list.

You can enter a program name and comment.
But this time just tap NEXT STEP to use the default program name and proceed.

Check the program name and comment.
Tap FINISH if it looks similar to the figure below.

Program creation with the guide has finished.
Tap HOME -> TUTORIAL -> Edit a program to go back to the tutorial.

Edit the program in the program editor.
Press the EDIT key to open the editor.
The editing program is automatically stored each time you make a change.
To go back to the tutorial, tap HOME -> TUTORIAL -> Edit a program.

Program Edit

Since, for this exercise, you did not create a program from scratch, but instead chose a template, you must now modify the program's positions to suit your needs.
Entering the program editor simply allows you to modify the template to suit your particular needs.
Jog the robot to an initial position from which the robot program is to start.

Move to Standby Position

Since all positions are unique to the robot's environment, the robot does not typically have pre-programmed positions. Therefore, you must create your own positions.
The Template Program, however, does have positions that serve as "placeholders" that you can modify for your use.
This position (standby) serves as a starting position and should provide clear access to the plates to be welded.

Note:
There are various names for this "standby" position. Sometimes it is called the "pounce" position.

Place a cursor on the "J P[1]" line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the robot position.
When the position is recorded, the number of P[1] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[1].

Record Standby Position

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.

Jog the robot to an approach point.
The approach point is about 100mm above the weld start point.

Move to Approach Point

It is usually not recommended to move directly from the standby or pounce position to the start of the weld.
Therefore, an intermediate position (approach position) is typically recorded just above the weld start point.

Place a cursor on the "L P[2]" line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the robot position.
When the position is recorded, the number of P[2] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[2].

Record Approach Point

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the -% key (override key) several times until 5% or less appears.
Jog the robot and place the torch at the weld start point.
The torch angle should be about 40 to 50 degrees to the workpiece.

Move to Weld Start Point

Care should be taken as we approach the weld start position so that we do not run the robot into the work.
Therefore it is recommended to slow the robot down to a controllable speed.

Note:
The angle of the torch can be adjusted as needed.

Place a cursor on the "L P[3]" line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the robot position.
When the position is recorded, the number of P[3] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[3].

Record Weld Start Point

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the -% key (override key) several times until 5% or less appears.
Jog the robot and place the torch at the weld end point.
The torch angle should be about 40 to 50 degrees to the workpiece.

Move to Weld End Point

Care should be taken as we approach the weld end position so that we do not run the robot into the work.
Therefore it is recommended to slow the robot down to a controllable speed.

Note:
The angle of the torch can be adjusted as needed.

Place a cursor on the "L P[4]" line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the robot position.
When the position is recorded, the number of P[4] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[4].

Record Weld End Point

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.

Jog the robot to an escape point.
The escape point is about 100mm above the weld end point.

Move to Escape Point

It is usually not recommended to move directly from the weld end position to the standby position.
Therefore, an intermediate position (escape position) is typically recorded just above the weld end point.

Place a cursor on the "L P[5]" line.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and tap TOUCHUP POINT to record the robot position.
When the position is recorded, the number of P[5] turns from red to black and "@" appears to the left of P[5].

Record Escape Point

Touchup replaces the selected motion instruction's existing positional information with the robot mechanical unit's current position.
Other motion instruction elements, such as speed or the way in which the robot moves, do not change.
The program editing has completed.

All steps in the "Edit a program" tutorial have been completed.
Tap BACK PREV and proceed to the "Perform welding" tutorial.

This tutorial guides you to execute the robot program you have created and perform arc welding.

You will experience the followings:
- Single step execution
- Continuous test execution
- Arc welding execution

 * You are required to complete "Edit a program" tutorial in advance.

Tap the HOME -> SELECT PROG. buttons to show a program list.
Tap the ARCWELD program you created in the "Edit a program" tutorial. The program editor will open and the program will be shown.
You can go back to this tutorial any time by tapping the HOME -> TUTORIAL -> Execute a program buttons.

Select Program

The HOME screen consists of four rows; SETUP, TEACH, RUN, and UTILITY.
The TEACH row will typically show the last program edited as the first item on the left. To the right of that, you are given the choice of SELECT PROG. and CREATE PROG.
As the name indicates, SELECT PROG. allows you to select a program from a list of programs which were already created.
CREATE PROG. allows you to create a new program.
Press the +% or -% key several times until 10% appears.

Motion Speed

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move.
When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed. The maximum value that can be chosen is 100%. Reducing the speed to 10% ensures that you have time to react to stop the robot, in case it does not operate as you anticipate.
Tap the first line of the shown program to select the starting line.

Select Starting Line

When a program is started, it will run starting from the line in the program that is currently selected. It is, therefore, necessary that you put the cursor on the first line in the program, if you would like to run the program from the beginning to the end.

If you position the cursor on a line other than the starting line, the program will start from that line instead.
In general it is a good idea to start at line 1 unless you know exactly what you are doing.

When Weld in the status window is turned on, press the WELD ENBL key to turn off the Weld LED.
Arc welding is disabled.

Switch Weld Enable Mode (Disabling)

To test the robot path before you weld, you want to make sure that the robot does not strike an arc for any reason until you are ready.
Therefore, during this step, arc welding is disabled.

When the Step in the status window is turned off, press the STEP key.
The Step LED will turn on and the single step execution mode will be selected.

Switch Execution Mode (Single Step Execution)

During the testing phase, you want to make sure that each line taught in the program works to your satisfaction.
Therefore, before you run the program continuously, you should run it step-by-step. Pressing the STEP key ensures that every time the FWD key is pressed, the program progresses by only one line, or step.

In Step mode, each time the FWD key is pressed, executing a motion instruction, the robot will move and then come to a stop when the destination is reached.

Hold DEADMAN and the SHIFT key, then press the FWD key repeatedly until the last line of the program.
One line of the program is executed with each key press.
* Robot does not move in an alarm state.

Single Step Execution

Since the Step indicator is lit, every time the FWD key is pressed the program will progress by only one line, or step. The SHIFT key must be held in conjunction with the FWD key to ensure safe operation.

The red triangle indicates that the robot will move during this step in the tutorial, and therefore caution should be observed.

Your robot will not move if, for some reason, your robot has a fault. You will have to clear the fault before you can move the robot.
After checking that 10% is specified for robot motion speed, press the STEP key and turn off the Step LED in the status window.

Switch Execution Mode (Continuous Test Execution)

If the robot performed satisfactorily in step mode, you can now run the robot through the program from beginning to end without stopping at each line.

Pressing the STEP key again will cause the Step indicator to turn off, indicating that the robot is no longer in step mode, but instead is in continuous mode.

Note:
The suggested speed of 10% may be too slow for some users.
Athough reducing the speed to 10% ensures that you have time to react to stop the robot in case it does not operate as you anticipate, some users might want to increase the speed slightly.
If you choose to raise the speed by pressing the +% key (override key), be careful!
Also note that holding the SHIFT key while pressing the +% key causes the speed to increase in large increments. This could result in the robot operating at a higher speed than intended.

Hold DEADMAN and the SHIFT key and press the FWD key. The program is executed from beginning to end at once.
* Robot does not move in an alarm state.

Continuous Test Execution

You are now ready to run in continuous mode. In continuous mode, the robot will proceed through the program without stopping until it gets to the end.
The SHIFT key must be held before the FWD key is pressed, to ensure safe operation.
After the FWD key is pressed once it can be released, but the SHIFT key must be held continuously while running the program or the program will stop.

Note:
In step mode, each time a motion instruction is executed, the robot will move and then come to a stop when the destination is reached.
In continuous mode, however, the program runs continually through each line in the program.
Because each motion instruction in the Tutorial Program ends in FINE, the robot will still decelerate and make a very brief stop at each position before proceeding to the next.
This deceleration, stopping, and subsequent acceleration might result in a noticeably less "smooth" path than you imagined.
Later, you might create a program wherein motion instructions end in CNT instead of FINE. If so, the robot will not necessarily stop at each position.
Depending on the number following CNT, at some point in its deceleration before a given position, the robot will "skirt around" the position it is approaching and move on to the next, resulting in a "smoother" path.
Of course, FINE is necessary at weld start and end positions as the robot needs to come to a stop before striking and ending an arc.

Hold the SHIFT key and press the WELD ENBL key to turn on the Weld LED in the status window.
Arc welding is enabled.

Switch Weld Enable Mode (Enabling)

Now that you have made sure that the robot moves through its path as expected, you are ready to weld.
Holding the SHIFT key while pressing the WELD ENBL key will light the Weld indicator, thus showing that welding is enabled.
Hold the DEADMAN switch and press the +% key (override key) several times until 100% appears.

Motion Speed (100% Speed)

The override speed restricts the speed at which the robot will move. When the robot is running a program, this speed is a percentage of the programmed speed.

You must set this speed at its maximum value of 100% to weld. The reason for this becomes apparent if you consider the following:
If you had the override speed set at 50%, for example, and your welding speed at 60cm/min, then the resulting weld speed would be 30cm/min.
Reducing the intended weld speed by half will probably not produce the results you were expecting.

Note:
If you want to increase or decrease the speed in large increments, you can hold the SHIFT key while pressing the speed override key.

Follow these safety precautions.

- Never look directly at a welding arc without appropriate eye protection.

- Stand back to avoid weld spatter.

- If anything goes wrong, stop the robot immediately.

Hold the DEADMAN switch and the SHIFT key, and press the FWD key.
Arc welding is performed.
* Robot does not move in an alarm state.

Perform Arc Welding

You are now ready to weld in continuous mode.
The SHIFT key must be held in conjunction with the FWD key to ensure safe operation. Once the FWD key is pressed, it can be released as long as SHIFT is continually held.

Caution:
Always wear appropriate safety clothing and eye protection when welding!

The red triangle indicates that the robot will move during this step in the tutorial.

Your robot will not move if, for some reason, your robot has a fault. You will have to clear the fault before you can move the robot.

After you are finished welding, check to see if the weld looks good.

Be careful! The workpiece will be extremely hot right after welding.

All steps in the "Perform welding" tutorial have been completed.
Tap BACK PREV to go back to the TUTORIAL screen.
